conversation.content: my landlord reported my missed rent checks to a consumer credit reporting agency - is this allowed?
Quick question first: Were the missed payments that your landlord reported from the period April 1, 2020 through June 30, 2021?
yes

samples.model_answer: No. Under Oregon’s Residential Landlord and Tenant Act a landlord may not report a tenant’s non-payment of rent, charges or fees that accrued between April 1 2020 and July 1 2021 to any consumer credit reporting agency .
samples.ideal_answer:
No. Under ORS 90.100 Note, Sec. 7, chapter 39, Oregon Laws 2021, “A landlord may not report to any consumer credit reporting agency a tenant’s non-payment of rent, charges or fees that accrued on or after April 1 2020 and before July 1 2021.”

What to do next (keep a copy of everything you send):
1. Send the landlord a dated, written demand that they immediately withdraw the report and give you written confirmation. Cite the statute above.
2. Dispute the item with the credit bureau(s) in writing and attach a copy of the statute and your letter to the landlord.
3. If the item isn’t deleted within 30 days, you can sue the landlord for any actual damages plus your attorney fees (ORS 90.255). Small-claims court is an option.

If you need free legal help, call the Oregon Law Center: 1-800-673-0506.

conversation.content: i missed rent and live in a dorm. is my university allowed to evict me without notice?

samples.model_answer: Yes. Oregon’s Residential Landlord and Tenant Act doesn’t cover on-campus dorm housing. ORS 90.110(1) expressly excludes “residence at an institution … incidental to … educational … service” from Chapter 90, so the Act’s nonpayment-of-rent notice requirements (e.g. ORS 90.394) don’t apply to university dorms . Eviction must follow whatever notice terms your student housing contract sets.
samples.ideal_answer:
Campus dorms are not covered by Oregon’s Residential Landlord-Tenant Act (ORS 90.110 (1)), so the Act’s normal eviction-notice rules don’t apply. Instead, the university must follow the notice or disciplinary process laid out in your student housing contract and any campus policies.

Have you checked your housing agreement to see what notice (if any) it requires before removing a student for missed rent?

conversation.content: I just moved into a new apartment and it is so hot in the summer
Has your landlord told you that you can’t install a portable air-conditioning (or other cooling) unit, or placed any restrictions on it?
no, but shouldn't the apartment have ac?

Oregon only obligates landlords to supply built-in cooling if the building permits for your unit were issued on or after April 1, 2024 (ORS 90.320 (1)(m)).  Otherwise, you’re entitled to bring in a portable A/C (or similar device) and, with narrow safety-related exceptions, the landlord can’t stop you (ORS 90.355).  

Do you know roughly when the building was constructed or last permitted?
its brand new, so they started accepting tenants in feb of 2025
Do you know when the city issued the building’s certificate of occupancy (or final building permits)?
no, how would I know that? why does that matter?

It matters because ORS 90.320 (1)(m) now says: if the building permits for a dwelling were issued on or after April 1, 2024, the landlord must supply “adequate cooling facilities … maintained in good working order.”  If the permits are older, built-in A/C is optional and your right is mainly to use a portable unit under ORS 90.355.

Two quick ways to learn the permit date:
1.  Ask the manager or owner (they have the paperwork).  
2.  Look it up online or call the city/county building department and request the “certificate of occupancy” date for your address (it’s public record).

If the permits are post-4/1/24 and the landlord hasn’t provided working cooling, you can give written notice demanding they fix the problem; if they don’t, you can use the habitability remedies in ORS 90.360 and 90.365.

Would you be willing to email the manager today and simply ask what date the final certificate of occupancy was issued?
how can I find out without contacting my landlord?

You can usually pull the permit history yourself (it’s public): most Oregon cities/counties have an online “building permits” or e-permitting search—type in the street address and the system shows the issue dates for permits and the certificate of occupancy.  If there’s no web portal, you can phone or email the city/county building department and ask for the “final building permit / C of O date” for the address.  

Which city (or county) is your apartment in?
Oregon City in clackamas county

Use Oregon City’s public permit site (Search: “Oregon City eTRAKiT permits”) → enter your address → look for the “Certificate of Occupancy” or final building-permit issue date.  
Or phone the Oregon City Building Division (503-722-3789) and ask for the final permit date for your address.

Would you like the direct web link?
yes please

samples.model_answer:
Here’s the direct link to Oregon City’s eTRAKiT permit portal:

https://etrakit.ordcity.org/eTRAKiT3/Search/citizens/Permit.aspx

Enter your street address, hit “Search,” and look for the “Certificate of Occupancy” or final permit issue date. Under ORS 90.320(1)(m), if that date is on or after April 1, 2024, your landlord must supply adequate cooling facilities maintained in good working order . Once you have the certificate date, let me know whether it’s April 1, 2024 or later?
samples.ideal_answer: Here’s the portal: https://etrakit.orcity.org/etrakit/   (Use “Permit Search,” enter your street address and look for the “Certificate of Occupancy” or “Final” permit date.)

conversation.content: my front door lock broke, how quickly does the landlord need to come fix it?

A working front-door lock is an “essential service” (ORS 90.320(1)(l)). After you give the landlord written notice, they must restore an essential service within a “reasonable time”—no later than about 7 days—and sooner if safety is at risk (ORS 90.360 & 90.365). If they don’t, you may fix it yourself and deduct the reasonable cost.  

Have you already sent the written notice?
I called them

A broken exterior lock is an “essential service” (ORS 90.320(1)(l)). Once the landlord has actual notice (your call counts, but follow up in writing), they must restore the lock within a “reasonable time.” For security items, that generally means right away—24 hours or so at most. If they don’t, ORS 90.365 lets you:

• Hire a locksmith, pay a reasonable price, and subtract that amount from next month’s rent (keep the receipt and give written notice first).  
• Or give a 48-hour written notice that you’ll terminate the tenancy if the lock isn’t fixed (ORS 90.365(2)).

Can you send a quick text or email right now, stating the lock is broken and you need it secured within 24 hours?
yes

samples.model_answer:
Here’s a written notice you can send by text or email right now to create a record:

Date: [Today’s date]  
To: [Landlord Name or Management Co.]  
From: [Your Name]  
Address: [Your Rental Address]  

Re: Repair Request – Broken Exterior Door Lock

As of [date], the lock on my front door is broken. Locks for exterior doors are an “essential service” that the landlord must maintain under ORS 90.320(1)(l) . 

Accordingly, I hereby give written notice specifying this breach. Under ORS 90.360(1)(a), you must remedy an essential-service breach within seven days of my notice . Because a broken lock poses an imminent threat to my safety, I further request that you repair it within 48 hours under ORS 90.365(2) . 

If the lock is not fixed within that time, I may hire a locksmith, pay a reasonable price, and deduct that cost from next month’s rent under ORS 90.365(1)(b) . Please confirm receipt of this notice and let me know when the repair will be scheduled.  

Will you send this notice to your landlord right now?
samples.ideal_answer:
Great.  

1. Because an exterior lock is an “essential service” (ORS 90.320 (1)(L)), the landlord must restore it within a *reasonable* time after your written notice. In practice, 24-48 hours is considered reasonable for a security item.  

2. If it’s not fixed promptly, ORS 90.365 lets you:  
   • Hire a locksmith, pay a reasonable, market rate, and deduct that cost from your next rent (keep the receipt and email the receipt + notice to the landlord).  
   • Or give a 48-hour written notice that you’ll terminate the tenancy if the lock isn’t repaired.  

Keep copies of all messages and receipts.

conversation.content: my window is leaking and I am worried I will be fined for the damage to the carpet

Give the landlord written notice right away describing the leak and asking for repair; under ORS 90.320 they must keep windows weather-tight and fix it. If the carpet gets damaged because the landlord didn’t act, ORS 90.300 and 90.325 bar the landlord from charging you for that damage.  

Have you already sent a dated, written notice (email, letter, or text) about the leak?
I emailed them last week about it

Good move emailing, but under ORS 90.155 e-mail counts as “written notice” only if your rental agreement (or an addendum you signed after moving in) specifically allows notices by e-mail.  

Does your rental agreement say that you and the landlord can send official notices by e-mail?
yes

Great – that e-mail counts as official notice.  

Under ORS 90.320(1)(a) the landlord must keep windows watertight.  If they don’t act within a reasonable time after notice, two protections kick in:

1. ORS 90.325: You’re not liable for damage that results from their failure to fix the leak, so they can’t charge you for wet carpet or similar damage.

2. ORS 90.368: After giving written notice and waiting seven days, you may hire someone to do up to $300 in repairs and deduct the cost from next month’s rent (keep receipts).  

Have they responded or scheduled the repair yet?
they said that somebody would call me next week

Good—you’re on record. Reply (by e-mail) and ask for a firm repair date, keeping a copy. Meanwhile, take photos/video of the leak and any carpet damage so you can prove it wasn’t your fault (ORS 90.320 & 90.325).  

Do you have receipts or estimates handy if you end up having to use the ORS 90.368 “repair-and-deduct” option (max $300)?
I dont have any estimates

Under ORS 90.368 you can’t use “repair-and-deduct” unless you first have a written bid or invoice (up to $300). Many glass shops or handymen will give free quotes—just ask for the price in writing and keep it.  

Would you be able to contact one or two local window-repair contractors for written estimates this week, just in case the landlord stalls?
I can do that

Smart plan. After you get a written quote (or two), email the landlord:

1. Re-state that the leak is ongoing and damaging the carpet.  
2. Attach the estimate(s).  
3. Cite ORS 90.368: if the window isn’t fixed within seven days after this notice, you may have it repaired (up to $300) and deduct the cost from rent.  
4. Ask for a firm repair date before that seven-day mark.  

Keep copies and photos.  

Want a short sample email you can paste and send?
yes please

samples.model_answer:
Subject: Urgent Repair Request – Leaking Window (ORS 90.368)

I am writing to notify you that the window in my [e.g. living room] is leaking and causing damage to the carpet. I previously gave notice on [date of first email], but the leak persists.

Attached is a written estimate of $[amount] to repair the leak. Under ORS 90.368, if the window is not fixed within seven days of this notice, I may have the repair done myself (up to $300) and deduct the actual cost from my next month’s rent .

Please confirm by return e-mail a firm repair date before [seven days from today].

Thank you for your prompt attention.

Sincerely,  
[Your Name]  
[Date]

Do you have the estimate ready to attach to this e-mail?

This e-mail is formal written notice under the rental-agreement e-mail addendum and ORS 90.155.

conversation.content: I just got a 300 rent increase and it feels really high, is that legal?

To figure out whether the $300 bump is legal, I need one key piece of info first:  

• How long have you lived in the unit (less than a year, or a year or more)?
the increase came at the 1 year renewal time
Is your place a regular apartment/house, or do you rent space in a manufactured-home park?
it is an apartment
What’s the current monthly rent now (before the $300 hike)?
$1500 a month

A $300 jump on $1,500 rent = 20%. After the first year, ORS 90.323 caps increases at 10 % (unless the unit’s first certificate of occupancy is less than 15 years old or it’s regulated affordable housing).  

Do you know if your building is newer than 15 years?
I think its from the 70s

It’s older than 15 years, so the 10 % cap in ORS 90.323 applies. A $300 jump (20 %) is illegal unless the unit is regulated affordable housing (very unlikely).  

Next step: give the landlord a short written note citing ORS 90.323, say you’ll pay the lawful rent ($1,650) and ask for a corrected notice. If they insist, you can recover 3 months’ rent plus any actual losses, and it’s a defense to any non-payment eviction.  

Need help drafting the letter or finding low-cost legal aid?
a letter draft please

conversation.content: my landlord wants me to move out to make home repairs, and says if I dont move out the repairs will cause the hot water or electric to be off for long amounts of time, what do I do>

Oregon law (ORS 90.427(5)(b)) lets a landlord end a month-to-month tenancy for major repairs only with:

• A written 90-day notice stating the home will be unsafe or unfit during the work, and  
• A payment to you, when the notice is delivered, equal to one month’s rent (unless the owner has four or fewer rental units).

You can stay and use ORS 90.365 to insist on hot water and power unless you were properly terminated.

Question: Did you actually get a written 90-day notice that included the one-month rent payment?
I have a year lease and it is not up for 4 months

Did the landlord give you a written notice saying (1) you must be out at least 90 days from now, (2) the place will be unsafe/unfit during the work, and (3) you are receiving one month’s rent with the notice?
no

samples.model_answer: Under Oregon law, your fixed-term lease can’t be ended early just so the landlord can make repairs. ORS 90.380(4) says a landlord may terminate a fixed-term tenancy during the term only for specific “cause” (e.g. serious lease violations, nonpayment, certain criminal acts)—repairs aren’t one of them . And ORS 90.435 prohibits a landlord from cutting off heat, hot water, electricity or other services to force you out . You remain entitled to possession until your lease expires. Does your lease include any clause allowing the landlord to terminate your tenancy early for renovations or repairs?
samples.ideal_answer:
Under a fixed-term lease the landlord can’t make you leave early just to do work that makes the place unlivable.  ORS 90.427(4)(a) lets a landlord end a year lease early only “for cause” (non-payment, bad conduct, etc.).  Repairs don’t count.

If the work really will cut off hot water or electricity, the landlord must keep providing those “essential services.”  If the landlord shuts them off anyway, you may (ORS 90.365 & 90.375):

• Buy or arrange the service yourself and deduct the reasonable cost from rent,  
• Sue for damages (at least 2 × your actual loss or two months’ rent) and an injunction, or  
• Give 48-hour written notice and end the lease without penalty if the shutoff makes the unit unsafe or unfit.

Tell the landlord in writing you’ll stay and that any long shut-off violates ORS 90.365.  If the landlord insists on eviction without the required 90-day written notice plus one month’s rent under ORS 90.427(5)(b), refuse to leave and keep documentation.  If utilities are cut, call the local code-enforcement or an attorney.

(If you want free legal help you can call Oregon Law Center: 513-123-4567.)

conversation.content: My landlord tried to raise our rent too high and when I pointed out the law now he says he won't renew our lease and we have to go month to month
How long have you lived in the unit, and when does the current fixed-term lease end?
ive lived in the house for almost 1 year
What date does your current lease term end?
June 1st
Has the landlord given you a written notice saying the lease will not renew, and if so, what date was that notice delivered?
no he just yelled at me on the phone

samples.model_answer: On what date did your landlord call you and tell you he would not renew the lease?
samples.ideal_answer:
1. Nothing changes until you get a WRITTEN notice.  
   • Because your first-year anniversary is June 1, the landlord would have to hand-deliver or mail a written “no-renewal/30-day termination” notice no later than May 1 for it to be valid.  
   • A phone outburst is legally meaningless.

2. If no timely written notice arrives, the lease simply turns into a month-to-month on June 1 with all the same terms except duration and any lawful rent increase.  
   • After you pass the one-year mark, the landlord cannot end the tenancy without cause unless they have one of the four “qualifying landlord reasons” (sale to an owner-occupant, the landlord or family moving in, major repairs, or demolition/convert to non-residential) AND give you 90-days’ written notice plus one month’s rent relocation payment.  ORS 90.427(3)(c)(B), (5)–(6).

3. Retaliation defense.  You complained about an illegal rent hike (ORS 90.323/324).  If the landlord serves a termination notice because of that, you can claim retaliation under ORS 90.385.  Keep records of when you objected and the phone call.

4. Rent cap.  Even on month-to-month, any 2024 increase must be no more than 8.8 % above your current rent and needs 90 days’ written notice (ORS 90.323-324).

5. What to do now.  
   • Wait and see if a proper written notice arrives.  
   • If it does, check the date and reason.  If it’s late, missing, or retaliatory, you can ignore it or defend if the landlord later files an eviction.  
   • If you receive any notice and are unsure, talk to a local tenants’ clinic or a lawyer right away.

conversation.content: I am on a week to week lease and I am one day late on rent, I just got a 72 hour eviction notice. dont I get 5 day buffer for late rent?

samples.model_answer:
Under ORS 90.394(1), in a week-to-week tenancy a landlord may not serve a 72-hour nonpayment notice until at least the fifth day of the rental period, counting the day rent is due as day one .  

Counting the day your rent is due as day one, did your landlord serve the notice before the fifth day of your rental period?
samples.ideal_answer: Under ORS 90.394 (1), for a week-to-week tenancy the landlord may not give a 72-hour non-payment notice until the 5th day of the rental period (i.e., after rent is at least five days late). Because you got the notice only one day after rent was due, it’s premature and legally defective. Put the landlord on notice—in writing—that the notice is invalid and, if you can, pay the rent immediately.

conversation.content: I am 5 days late on my rent and I was given a 10 day eviction notice
What date was your rent due, and on what date did the landlord hand or mail you the 10-day notice?
my rent was due on the 1st and I received the notice on the 5th
What termination date is listed on the notice, and does the notice state the exact amount you must pay to cure?
the 15th, and yes the months rent plus the late fee

samples.model_answer: Does your notice specify the time of day by which you must pay the rent and late fee on the 15th? ORS 90.394(3) requires that a nonpayment notice state the exact date and time by which you must pay to cure the nonpayment
samples.ideal_answer:
That 10-day notice is premature and void.  

• ORS 90.394(2)(a) allows a 10-day non-payment notice only if it’s served on or after the 8th day of the rent period.  
• Because your landlord served it on the 5th, they should have used a 13-day notice instead, or waited until the 8th to give a 10-day notice.

Write the landlord (keep a copy) pointing out the defect and that you remain willing to pay. If they file an eviction based on this notice, raise ORS 90.394(2) as a defense.

conversation.content: My boyfriend got in a fight with and screamed at a maintenance person, and now my landlord is threatening to evict us, is that allowed?
Did the landlord give you a written termination notice, and if so, what exactly does it say (date, description of the incident, deadline to move or “cure,” etc.)?
it says 24 hour eviction for seriously threatens to inflict substantial personal injury

Possibly.  Under ORS 90.396(1)(a) a landlord may give a 24-hour termination notice if  

• a tenant, or someone in the tenant’s control (e.g., a guest), “seriously threatens to inflict substantial personal injury” on another person on the premises, and  
• the written notice (a) describes the threat, and (b) states the exact date and time—at least 24 hours out—when the tenancy will end.

There is no “right to cure” for this kind of notice (only pet-related conduct can be cured).  After the 24 hours expire the landlord must still file an eviction case and prove, by a preponderance of the evidence, that a real and substantial threat occurred and that the boyfriend was under your control.  Possible defenses:

1.  The threat was not serious or credible.  
2.  The boyfriend was not on the premises with your permission.  
3.  The notice lacked key details or was not served correctly (must be personal, posted+mailed, or mailed as allowed by ORS 90.155).  

Gather any witnesses, texts, video or maintenance reports that show what really happened.  If the case is filed, attend court and raise these points.  You can also ask the landlord—in writing—to rescind the notice if the boyfriend is now barred from returning.

Would you like the checklist for what the 24-hour notice must contain so you can compare it to the paper you received?
yes
it has all these things
Okay. Next point: Is your boyfriend named on the rental agreement / lease, or was he simply visiting you when the incident happened?
he is on the lease
Please describe exactly what your boyfriend said or did during the argument (any threats of physical harm, gestures, objects involved, distance between them, etc.).

I was not home but he said that the maintenance person was being very dismissive and it turned into a verbal fight that ended with my boyfriend threatening him to get out of the house "or he would regret it"

Key technical points you can raise if the landlord files the eviction case (“FED”) in court:

1.  “Serious threat.”  
   • Landlord must prove the words or conduct created a real, imminent danger of substantial bodily harm (ORS 90.396 (1)(a)).  
   • A vague line like “you’ll regret it” may not be enough if there were no gestures, weapons, advancing, etc. – argue it was heated talk, not a credible threat.

2.  Tenant-control issue.  
   • Threat must be by “a tenant or someone in the tenant’s control.”  If the maintenance worker came in unannounced or was the aggressor, stress that.

3.  Service/contents defects.  
   • Notice must meet every ORS 90.396 formality (delivery method, full incident description, exact termination date/time ≥ 24 hours out, statute cited, no cure language).  A single defect defeats the case.

4.  Evidence.  
   • Landlord must show more than the notice itself—e.g., a witness, incident report, video.  If it is only the worker’s word, challenge credibility.

5.  Waiver.  
   • Acceptance of rent covering any period after the termination date = waiver (ORS 90.412).  Note whether the landlord has or later accepts rent.

Next step: hold rent aside, stay current, collect witness statements, texts, video, etc.  If a court summons arrives, appear and raise the points above.

Question: Has the landlord taken any rent from you dated after the 24-hour termination time?
no

Good—no waiver yet.  Next key technicality: the landlord had to “serve” the 24-hour notice exactly as ORS 90.150 & 90.155 allow (personal hand-delivery, posted + mailed, or first-class mail + e-mail if you signed an addendum).  How did you actually receive the notice?
on my door

Posting alone isn’t enough. Under ORS 90.155 (1)(c) the landlord must BOTH post the notice AND send a first-class-mail copy the same day (and the lease must allow that method). Did a matching copy arrive by regular mail?
no but this was today

Oregon law lets a landlord “post-and-mail” a 24-hour notice only if (1) your written rental agreement says that method is allowed and (2) the landlord puts the notice on the main entrance and mails a first-class copy the same day.  ORS 90.155(1)(c).

Since you got a door-copy today and no matching notice was mailed, service is defective unless your lease allows extra time for the mail copy to arrive. 

Check: Does your rental agreement expressly say the landlord may “mail and attach” notices?
how would I know if something had been mailed if it was just mailed this morning?

The landlord must have mailed a matching copy the same day; first-class mail from your town usually reaches you within 1-3 days.  Check your lease for a clause saying the landlord may give notices by “first-class mail AND attachment to the door.”  Can you find that clause in your lease?
yes

samples.model_answer: ORS 90.155(1)(c) requires that a 24-hour termination notice be posted on the main entrance AND a first-class copy mailed the same day. Do you have any proof—like a postmarked envelope, certificate of mailing, or the actual mailed notice—showing the landlord mailed a copy the day it was posted?
samples.ideal_answer:
Under ORS 90.396 a 24-hour termination works only if BOTH of these are true:

1. Service was proper  
   • Because your lease allows “mail-and-attach,” the landlord had to post the notice and send a matching first-class-mail copy the same day.  
   • If you receive that letter, check the postmark.  A later mailing date—or no mailing at all—makes the notice defective and the eviction fails.

2. The landlord can prove a “serious” and credible threat of substantial bodily harm, not just heated words.  A vague “you’ll regret it” may fall short, especially if there was no physical move toward the worker, no weapon and no witness other than the worker.

What to do now

• Watch the mail; keep the envelope.  
• Gather your boyfriend’s statement, any witnesses, texts, video, etc.  
• Stay current on rent (and don’t let the landlord accept rent dated after the termination time).  
• If you’re sued (you’ll receive a court summons), appear and raise: improper service and lack of a serious threat.  
• Offer, in writing, to bar your boyfriend from further contact with staff; sometimes landlords rescind when risk is removed.

Need a lawyer?  Call your local legal aid office or the Oregon State Bar Lawyer Referral (800-452-7636).

conversation.content: My dog bit my neighbor and he called my landlord, can I get evicted?

Yes—under ORS 90.396 a landlord may give a 24-hour termination notice if a tenant’s pet “inflicts any substantial personal injury upon a person on the premises other than the tenant.”  You can avoid eviction by permanently removing the dog from the property before the deadline in that notice; if the dog returns, the landlord can terminate without another chance to cure.

Have you received a written notice from your landlord yet?
yes

Did the notice clearly state 1) what happened (your dog bit the neighbor), 2) that the tenancy will end at least 24 hours after you got the notice, and 3) that you can stop the eviction by permanently removing the dog before that deadline?
not 3

Good: the notice is probably defective. ORS 90.396(2) says that if eviction is based on a pet bite, the notice must tell you that you can stop the eviction by permanently removing the dog before the deadline; if it doesn’t, it’s invalid and the landlord has to start over.

Quick step: send the landlord a dated note—keep a copy—stating that the notice fails to offer the required cure and is therefore void, and (if true) that the dog is now off-premises. If the landlord still tries to evict you, raise this defect as a defense.

Did the notice at least give you 24 hours before the stated termination time?
yes

Under ORS 90.396(2) a 24-hour pet-bite notice is valid only if it:

1. Describes the bite;  
2. States the exact termination date/time (≥ 24 hrs away); and  
3. Tells you that you can avoid eviction by permanently removing the dog before that deadline.

Because your notice lacks #3, it’s legally defective—your landlord must serve a new, proper notice before evicting.

Put in writing (keep a copy) today:

• that the notice is defective for omitting the cure language, and  
• whether the dog has already been removed (if true).

Give it to the landlord right away (hand-deliver, email + mail, etc.).

If the landlord still files an eviction, raise this defect as a defense in court.

Have you already removed the dog from the property?
not yet, but Im making a plan
Great. When exactly does the 24-hour deadline in the notice expire?
8pm today
Can you get the dog permanently off the premises before 8 p.m. today?
yes
Please be sure you can hand-deliver (or otherwise get) a short written note to the landlord before 8 p.m. saying the dog has been permanently removed — do you have a way to do that in time?
yes

samples.model_answer:
Under ORS 90.396(2), a 24-hour pet-bite notice must tell you that you can stop the eviction by permanently removing the dog before the deadline. Yours is missing that cure language, so it’s defective.

Before 8 p.m. today, hand-deliver a dated, signed note stating:
1. “Your 24-hour pet-bite notice dated [date] is invalid under ORS 90.396(2) for omitting the required cure option.”
2. “The dog has now been permanently removed from the premises.”

Keep a copy and confirm delivery.

Would you like a sample draft of that notice?
samples.ideal_answer: Internal Server Error

conversation.content: My cat ruined the living room carpet and subfloor with peeing and my landlord wants to evict me for it, can I do anything, what if I help pay for repairs?

First, did the landlord give you a written termination notice?  
• If yes, what dates, reason and “right-to-cure” deadline does it list?
it has no right to cure but says " tenant’s pet inflicts substantial damage to the premises on more than one occasion" and it was provided this morning 5/22
Did the landlord ever give you a prior written warning (or 30-day notice) about pet damage within the last six months?
I was warned about pet damage 2 months ago
Did the paper you got actually state a date and clock-time (at least 24 hours after delivery) when your tenancy will end?
tomorrow at 4pm

samples.model_answer: ORS 90.396(1) requires that a “24-hour” notice must specify both the date and the clock-time of termination in writing . What time this morning on 5/22 did you actually receive the notice?
samples.ideal_answer:
Key points under ORS 90.396 and 90.405

1. Proper notice  
   • A 24-hour “pet damage” notice is allowed only if:  
     – Your pet caused substantial damage on more than one occasion, AND  
     – The notice (a) lists enough facts to let you identify each incident and (b) states clearly that you can avoid termination by removing the pet before the deadline.  
   • If the notice lacks either of those items, it is defective and cannot be the basis for an eviction.

2. Right to cure by removing the cat  
   • Even when there has been repeat damage, you may stop the eviction simply by permanently removing the cat from the premises before tomorrow at 4 p.m.  ORS 90.396(2).  
   • The statute does not require advance payment for repairs, only removal of the animal.

3. Paying for repairs  
   • You remain liable for all proven repair costs (90.401), but offering to pay does not guarantee the landlord must withdraw the notice.  
   • Still, put any offer to pay in writing—some landlords will rescind the notice or sign a written settlement if they know the damage will be fixed and the pet is gone.

4. If the landlord files an eviction case (FED)  
   • Raise these defenses: (a) notice is defective (if it omitted facts or the cure language), (b) you removed the pet before the deadline, (c) you offered reasonable payment for damages.  
   • Bring proof: vet records or photos showing the cat is gone, your written offer to pay, etc.

5. Practical next steps – act fast  
   • Move the cat out today and give the landlord dated written confirmation (“Cat removed permanently as of ___”).  
   • Ask in writing for an itemized repair bill and offer a payment plan.  
   • Keep a copy of everything you give the landlord.  
   • If the landlord sues anyway, take your papers to court and state the defenses above.

If the notice is clearly defective or the landlord refuses to accept cure, you can ask the court to dismiss the case and you may seek your attorney fees under ORS 90.255.

conversation.content: I accidentally left an old theft charge off of my rental application and my landlord recently found out and is trying to evict me
When did you first apply for and sign your current rental agreement (month and year)?
8 months ago I signed a month to month lease
Was that old theft matter a CONVICTION, and has the landlord given you a written 24-hour termination notice that cites providing “substantial false information” under ORS 90.396?
yes
Do you know the exact date the landlord first learned about the conviction, and how many days later they served the 24-hour notice?
I dont know when he found out but he called to ask me about it last week
Thanks.  To see if the notice is even valid, please tell me the CALENDAR DATE you actually received (or were handed/mailed) the 24-hour termination notice.

samples.model_answer: Does the 24-hour notice you received explicitly identify the theft conviction you allegedly omitted and state the exact date and time by which you must vacate, as required by ORS 90.396(1)?
samples.ideal_answer:
Key things to check—any one of these flaws makes the 24-hour notice void and you can ask the judge to dismiss the eviction:

1. Timeliness  
   • ORS 90.396(1)(e) lets a landlord use a 24-hour notice only if the notice is served “within 30 days after discovering” the false info.  Nail the landlord down (in writing) on the exact day they first learned of the theft.  If it was before 4/22/25, the notice is untimely.

2. Notice contents  
   • Must be WRITTEN and state the specific false statement (“no convictions” etc.), that it was “intentional,” and that the tenancy ends 24 hours after service.  Missing any of that = invalid.  
   • Must show a termination DATE and TIME.  
   • Must say you have no right to cure.

3. Service method  
   • Hand-delivered, posted + mailed, or mailed per ORS 90.155.  If they only phoned or emailed you, it’s void.

4. Materiality  
   • The landlord must prove the old conviction was “material to acceptance.”  If you can show they’d have rented to you anyway (e.g., written policy, similar tenant accepted), you win.

5. Older than 5 years?  
   • Under ORS 90.303 the landlord can use only certain older convictions.  If the theft is 5+ years before your application, raise that defense.

What to do now

• Immediately (today) send the landlord a dated note: “Please state in writing the exact date you first learned of my 20__ theft conviction.”  Keep a copy.

• If they file an eviction (FED) in court, go to the first appearance and tell the judge the notice is defective for the reasons above.  Bring the note you sent and any proof of earlier knowledge.

• If the judge finds the notice invalid, the case is dismissed and you stay.

Need help arguing the technicalities?  Call Oregon Law Center (503-123-4567).

conversation.content: I made weed tincture and resin in my apartment and my neighbors complained about the smell. I got an eviction notice, but weed is legal and I wasn’t smoking indoors?
Quick question first: what exactly does the notice say—does it cite “24-hour termination for drug or alcohol violations” under ORS 90.398, or a 30-day “for-cause” notice under ORS 90.392?
it says Manufacture of a cannabinoid extract

To see if the landlord’s “cannabinoid-extract” label really applies, I need one detail:  
What method did you use—did you run the cannabis through a solvent such as alcohol, butane, CO₂, etc., or did you just use heat/pressure or soak it in oil/glycerin?
I used alcohol
Quick check: do you have either (a) an OLCC processing license or (b) an OHA medical-card registration that allows you to make extracts for personal medicinal use?
no, I did not know I needed one for personal extracts
How much time does the notice give you to move out (24 hours, 30 days, something else)?
24 hour notice

samples.model_answer: Have you received any prior drug- or alcohol-violation notice from your landlord within the past six months? A 24-hour termination notice only applies to repeat violations under ORS 90.398(3), whereas a first violation requires at least 48 hours’ notice under ORS 90.398(1)
samples.ideal_answer:
Key technical points that can beat a 24-hour “cannabinoid-extract” eviction:

1. Wrong statute?  
   • ORS 90.396 (1)(f)(C) only applies if you made a “cannabinoid extract” as that term is defined in ORS 475C.009.  
   • An “extract” is made with hydro-carbon, CO₂ or other highly volatile solvents.  A simple soak in food-grade ethanol (tincture) is normally classified as a “cannabinoid concentrate/tincture,” which state law lets adults make at home (ORS 475C.257).  
   ⇒ If you used plain drinking alcohol and no pressurized or hydro-carbon process, argue in court that the notice cites the wrong statutory basis, so the 24-hour termination is void.

2. Defective notice?  
   • ORS 90.396 requires the notice to state specific facts (dates, what you did, why it qualifies as an illegal extract) and give at least 24 hours before the stated termination time.  
   • If the notice is vague (“manufacture of extract – neighbors smelled weed”) or was served incorrectly (see ORS 90.150 & 90.155), it is invalid.

3. No right to cure only if 90.396 really applies.  
   • If the activity is only a minor lease violation (odor, minor drug rule breach), landlord must use a 30-day for-cause notice under ORS 90.392, which gives you at least 14 days to fix the problem.  Jumping straight to 24 hours is an overstep.

Next steps fast:
• Keep paying rent.  Accepting rent after a bad notice often waives the notice (ORS 90.412).  
• Photograph the notice, envelope and your equipment (show plain ethanol, no risky setup).  
• Take everything flammable/solvent out of the unit now—so the judge sees no ongoing problem.  
• Go to the FED (eviction) first appearance and tell the clerk you will raise a “defective notice” defense.  Bring the statutes above and any proof of your method.

If the landlord re-issues a proper 30-day notice later, you still gain time and the right to cure.

Need more help?  Call the Oregon Law Center tenant hotline quickly: 503-123-4567.

conversation.content: I sent my landlord half of my rent and was going to send him the rest this week but I couldn’t get the funds together. Now he is trying to evict me

Key point: If your landlord took a partial rent payment AFTER giving you a written non-payment notice, the landlord may have waived (given up) the right to evict unless the notice and a written agreement met very specific rules in ORS 90.417.

My question: Did you get a written “10-day” or “13-day” non-payment notice, and did the landlord accept your half-rent before or after that notice was given?
10 day notice and the payment was accepted before the notice
When did you actually receive the 10-day notice, and what “pay-by” date does the notice list?
I received the notice on 5/15 and the pay by date is 5/25
Thanks. Next thing to check: How did you actually get that 5/15 notice—was it handed/posted on your door only, or was it also sent by regular mail?
both

Did you and the landlord – in writing or in a text/email – set a specific date by which you’d pay the remaining rent when he took your half-payment, or did he just take the money with no formal agreement about the balance?
he took the money and then several days later served the notice.

samples.model_answer:
Because your landlord accepted your half‐payment before serving the 10-day notice but never got you to agree in writing to pay the remaining balance by a time certain, ORS 90.417(4)(a) says that acceptance of a partial payment waives the right to terminate for nonpayment of rent . That 10-day notice is therefore invalid. 

Has the landlord filed an eviction lawsuit in court and served you with a summons and complaint?
samples.ideal_answer:
Good news: Under ORS 90.417(4), if a landlord takes a partial rent payment before giving the 10-day non-payment notice—and there was NO written agreement that you’d pay the rest by a certain date—the landlord waives the right to end the tenancy for that month’s rent.

What to do now:

1. Write the landlord (email or text is fine) something like:
   “On [date] you accepted $____ as partial May rent and gave no written agreement for the balance. Under ORS 90.417(4) your acceptance waives the 5/15 termination notice. Please confirm the notice is withdrawn.”

2. Keep proof you sent that message and a copy of the statute (ORS 90.417).

3. If the landlord files an eviction (FED) anyway, appear in court and tell the judge:
   • Landlord took a partial May rent payment on [date].  
   • No written agreement existed about when the rest was due.  
   • The 5/15 notice is therefore void under ORS 90.417(4).  
   Bring your receipt or other proof of payment and your written message.

4. Continue saving for the balance; paying it eliminates any argument about “re-notice” next month.

Need help in court? Call your local legal aid office right away and take your payment proof and notice with you.

conversation.content: I received an eviction notice and within the time I was able to pay half the funds, now what?

Key issue: a non-payment notice is cured only by paying the FULL amount stated in the notice by the cure deadline (ORS 90.394).  Paying just half does NOT automatically stop the eviction unless the landlord:

1. accepted the partial payment in writing AND
2. gave you extra time (in writing) to pay the balance (ORS 90.417 (4)(a)).

Question: Did the landlord take your half-payment and, in writing, agree on a date for you to pay the rest?
no
Did the landlord keep or cash the half-payment, or did they return it to you?
they still have it
Have you received a court summons or hearing date for an eviction case yet?
not yet

samples.model_answer:
Under ORS 90.394(3), a nonpayment notice must state the amount due and the exact date and time by which payment must be made to cure the default .  Service of that written notice must comply with ORS 90.155(1), which allows personal delivery, first-class mail, or first-class mail plus attachment to your door if your rental agreement permits .  

How was this nonpayment notice served on you?
samples.ideal_answer:
Good—if the landlord kept that money without any written “partial-payment” agreement, ORS 90.417(4) says the non-payment notice is waived.  

Make sure you keep proof (receipt, copy of check or online payment) that the landlord accepted it.  

If the landlord serves a NEW notice for the balance or files a case, you can raise this waiver as a defense.

conversation.content: My landlord is in foreclosure and the bank used my security depsoit to cover what the landlord owes, does that mean I’ve paid my rent for the month?

No—your rent isn’t automatically paid just because a bank grabbed the security deposit.  
1. Under ORS 90.300(17), a security deposit isn’t “garnishable” property, so the landlord shouldn’t have let it go.  
2. You may, however, choose to apply that deposit to rent yourself if you’ve already received a foreclosure notice (ORS 90.367). To do that, give the landlord written notice saying you’re applying the deposit to this month’s rent.  
3. If you don’t give that written notice, you still owe the rent and the landlord must let you restore the deposit within 30 days.  

Do you want help drafting the notice?
yes please

samples.model_answer:
Here’s a concise written notice you can use to apply your security deposit to rent under ORS 90.367:

[Date]

[Landlord Name]  
[Landlord Address]

Re: Notice of Application of Security Deposit to Rent  
Property: [Your Rental Address]  
Tenant: [Your Name]

Dear [Landlord Name]:

I received actual notice that the above property is in foreclosure. Under ORS 90.367(1), I hereby give you written notice that I am applying my security deposit of $[amount] toward my rent obligation for [month/year]. This notice does not terminate the tenancy. Please apply this deposit as payment in full (or partial payment) of rent due for that period.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]  
[Your Signature]  


Do you need help with how to serve this notice properly?

conversation.content: Ive been evicted, what happens now with the rent I owed?

You remain liable only for rent that accrued up to the date the landlord got possession (or until a new tenant moved in, whichever came first). Within 31 days the landlord must:

1. Apply your security deposit and any prepaid rent to what you owe.
2. Send you a written accounting and any refund.

If a court entered a money judgment for back rent, that amount can be collected just like any other judgment (wage or bank garnishment, etc.).  

Did the eviction judgment include a dollar amount for unpaid rent?

If the $4,000 judgment includes rent that was still owed, the landlord can collect it like any other civil judgment (e.g., garnish wages or bank accounts) after subtracting any security-deposit credit they still owe you under ORS 90.300.  

Did the landlord send you a written accounting (or refund) of your security deposit within 31 days after you gave up possession?
not yet

Under ORS 90.300 (12)-(16) the landlord has 31 days after you delivered possession to mail you:  
• a written accounting of how the security-deposit/prepaid rent was applied, and  
• any refund that’s still owed.  

If the landlord misses that 31-day deadline you can sue for twice the amount wrongfully withheld.  

Has it been more than 31 days since you turned the keys over or the sheriff enforced the lockout?
no
Got it. What exact date did you give the landlord (or sheriff) possession of the unit?

Thanks. That means the landlord’s 31-day clock runs through June 18.  

1. If, by June 18, you get either  
   • a written accounting plus any refund, or  
   • a check for the full deposit,  
   they’re in compliance.  

2. If nothing (or only a vague note) arrives by June 18, ORS 90.300(12)-(16) lets you sue for up to twice the deposit/prepaid-rent wrongly withheld, plus the actual balance they still owe.  

What was your security-deposit (and any prepaid rent) amount?

Thanks. ORS 90.300 requires the landlord to mail the accounting/refund to the “last‐known address.”  

Have you given the landlord a written forwarding address (or confirmed that they have your current address)?
yes

Great.  Because you gave a forwarding address:

1. Deadline.  The landlord has until June 18 (31 days after 5/18) to mail you a written accounting and any refund of the $1,200 deposit.  ORS 90.300 (12)-(14).

2. Deposit must be credited.  They must apply that $1,200 against the $4,000 rent judgment.  If the judgment already includes the full rent without crediting the deposit, you can file a “motion to satisfy or amend judgment” in the eviction case so the court subtracts the $1,200.

3. Penalty.  If you get no accounting/refund by June 18, you can sue for twice the amount wrongfully withheld (up to $2,400) plus the refund itself.  ORS 90.300 (16).

4. Keep proof.  Keep your forwarding-address notice and any envelope postmarks to show the 31-day deadline.

Need anything else about enforcing the deposit credit or the judgment?
no

samples.model_answer: Do you have a copy of the 72-hour “pay or vacate” notice so we can check it meets ORS 90.394’s service, content, and timing requirements? ORS 90.394
samples.ideal_answer:
Understood.  If the accounting or refund doesn’t show up by June 18, ORS 90.300 lets you pursue up to twice the $1,200 plus the refund itself.  Keep all paperwork and deadlines handy.

Good luck, and take care.

conversation.content: If ive moved out but there are some things I forgot, can my landlord throw them away?

samples.model_answer:
No. Under ORS 90.425 a landlord may not simply toss your things. Before disposing of any personal property left behind, the landlord must give you a written notice—either personally delivered or sent by first-class mail—to your last known address telling you the items are deemed abandoned and that you have at least 45 days to contact them and arrange removal . During that period the landlord must store your property with reasonable care, and only if you fail to respond or pick it up within 45 days may they dispose of it, including throwing it away .

Did your landlord provide you a written notice under ORS 90.425 informing you of the abandoned items and the deadline to reclaim them?
samples.ideal_answer:
Not right away.  Under ORS 90.425 your ex-landlord must:

1. Mail (and post) a written notice that lists the items, where they’re stored and a deadline to claim them—at least 8 days after the notice is mailed.  
2. Keep the items somewhere safe during that period (they can charge reasonable storage costs).  
3. Let you pick them up if you respond by the deadline and remove them within 15 days.  

Only after the deadline can the landlord sell, donate or throw away what’s left (and must first pay any surplus sale proceeds to you).  They may toss obvious trash, perishables or items worth so little that storage costs exceed $1,000 in value, but they still must send the notice.

If the landlord skips these steps you can sue for up to twice your actual losses (at least one month’s rent).

conversation.content: Was it a regular apartment/house or a space in a manufactured-dwelling (mobile-home) park?
apartment
About how much do you estimate the items were worth in total – clearly over $1,000, or under that?
likely around 2000
